comments.commentBody:
I would say the thesis of this piece is inaccurate and suffers its own conceit of trying to posit its own version of breaking down orthodoxy. Just as it seeks to dispell the "orthodoxy" of Moneyball thinking, however, it's wrong, and more flash than substance.

In fact, what Moneyball and its following era have done was simply to reinforce a fact in baseball that, for a time, was overshadowed by the big-market, spendthrift thinking, namely, that the crucial element in putting together a great baseball team isn't money or statistics or scouting, but, above all, a shrewd, experienced and skilled manager. Billy Beane didn't prove that one can always put together a winner with limited resources; he proved that the best managers can do far better with far less than just create losers.

As Tim Elas and others have pointed out, the Rays have continued to succeed in a tiny market, mainly because of the skills and acumen of their managers.

The Baseball Prospectus article linked to is fascinating. However, it only reinforces the argument that smaller payrolls handicap teams and, beyond that, it points this out as a historical phenomenon, dating to the turn of the 20th century. In other words, it provides evidence directly controverting Mr. Mahler's thesis.

None of the teams in the current playoffs would have got here if ownership hadn't been willing to increase their payrolls to improve the teams midway into the seasons. In other words, the owners's support was necessary (but not sufficient) for the teams to get further.

The real takeaway from all of this is that a team which doesn't have the support of its ownership is likely to continue to fail. In addition, no matter how much money someone throws at the problem, this won't necessary solve systemic deficiencies or poor decision making by GMs. The Mets failed not because of a lack of resources, but because Minaya didn't know what he was doing. Guess how orthodox and conventional this all sounds?

It's the same as the unions that protect their members, police, teachers, local, state and federal goverment officals.  Code of Silence.  Union dues pay for legal support.  DWI with a cop at the wheel...MTA employee with hand in the cookie jar, local town highway  supervisor arrested on felony and misdesmeanor chargers, teacher caught with pornography, hedge fund manager guilty of X$B of dollars lost forever, sent to fed club ( look that up folks) and wife and family comfortable without husband ( replaceable ), state senator sentenced to 3 years out, in 85% of his sentencing on full pension. health care, etc.  In my next life I want to be a college graduate that works his way up through the public sector. through time in service, not 'result oriented), not subjected to  ( quotas, no ' if you don't this or else', the budget wasn't approved).  Oh. by the way did I mention that I hurt my back  at he water cooler lifting 5 gallons of water...disability.  MTA gets how much in this scam...for office workers. Police, firemen, Sanitation it's a scam worthy of Bernie Madoff.

The Catholic Church makes it up as they go along, from creating a Pope that's supposed to be infallible to celibacy which is contrary to The Bible. I know many Catholics who worship their Lord and Savior Jesus Christ and have a spiritual bent because they read the word of God rather than obey blasphemy from Rome. This so-called church has a history of sin and moral depravity. God is not mocked...

"The bishop has acknowledged that he knew of the existence of the photos last December but did not turn them over to the police until May. "

That's called being a accessory, and is a crime, pure and simple. Anyone not wearing Bishops clothing would have been in prison long ago.

The prosecuter who did this feat,deserves to be nominated for Nobel peace prize by none else but the Pope himself,for having guts and nerves to call a spade a spade,despite the sensitivity and volatility of the issue.

In 2009, this same Bishop declared "war" on, Obama, for his stance on abortion, "religious pluralism, and Catholic dissenters."

He named as "enemies" those who believe in religious tolerance and who seek common ground as opposed to those who take a "militant" approach to Catholicism.

And yet he protects a pedophile priest from prosecution.

If women were allowed to be priests they wouldn't tolerate pedophiles. They'd clean their clocks.

randh2 wrote, "I generally think the priest pedophilia scandal is blown out of proportion, and is on par with abuses by public school teachers and coaches."

You can think that all you want, but doing so doesn't make it true. Celibacy is obviously very frustrating for priests whether they are hetero or homosexual. Far higher rate of abuse by priests than public school teachers, you can be sure of that.

OMG. What a failure to protect the innocent!

I came back to school on a Mondya years ago to learn why my student had been absent the Friday before. She and a cousin, both under 16, had been lured to a hotel by some boys they met at Chuckie Cheese who drugged them and raped them and left them to pick up the hotel tab when they awoke the next day.

I found out from a teacher who had been told by her own students they'd heard this through the grapevine. I immeditley called the police and met them in my Vice Principle's office. Why did anyone wait for me to make the call? It's all our responsibility.

The police were fabulous, and the surgury the child had been denied by a neglagent mother was also accomplished forthwith. I love a fine running social infrastructure. Rapists BEWARE!!

Anyone entrusted with the safety of children is obligated to report knowledge of their abuse to the correct authorities. CPS if it's home induced, and the police otherwise.

To AJ SCOTT #101 in Texas

You took my words out of context and twisted the meaning. My forgiveness is not for the priest, but for the bishop who was caught in the middle of this. That was quite a hack job you did on my comment no. 59, so I will add it here, if I may;
The crime's were wrong and the priest should be in jail or therapy, but the people of the Kansas City diocese are clearly a lynch mob, something America is famous as.
I never liked that "Failure to report" law. The Cop's rarely tell us anything, do they? It's them and us.
I'm appalled that Kansas City indicted the Bishop. When America goes after religious leaders, it shows the total collapse of principals and morals in America. It's turned into a predjudice.
The bedrock principal of the Catholic church, based on the teaching of Jesus, is forgiveness, something America never does, as is totally missing in this case. I think the members of the Church should leave the country for their safety.

150. We can't send our kids to church. Really. Imagine that.
------------------------
The California legislature just mandated that elementary schools start teaching about the wunnerful world of homosexuality. Imagine that: sexualized 3rd graders; Jon Benet, the hussy. No wonder the Anti-bullying Law is so sorely desired by the insecure liberal parents - the childrens' consciousness has been raised, you see, but not in a life-affirming way. Tiger moms sense a threat.

I'll take my chances in the Catholic schools, thank you very much.

It is such a scandal how The civil Law has allowed the church hierarchy to make their own laws regarding their own crimes and how they need to proceed. The church commits the crimes, they absolve themselves, they are the court room , the judges, the attorneys...why are the laws different for these criminals? little girls were violated here, who is going to speak on their behalf? I am against the death penalty of innocent people, the hierarchy of the church and their counterparts are worthy of it.
If this accusation is true then send him to prison. If he failed in his duty to God and Man, a Bishop no less, then he should spend many years locked away as a warning and example to others.

comments.userDisplayName: Sexual abuse of children in the Catholic Church
comments.commentBody: This goes all the way to the top.  The current pope, while Cardinal Ratzinger, knew about abuse of children but did nothing.  This is criminal let alone immoral.  All must pay for this terrible abuse of power.

Anyone who has a duty to protect a child in his or her custody or care and fails to discharge that duty must go to prison.  If only the prosecutors in every county where this has occurred had the courage to do the same thing...

Does anyone know why it would just be a misdemeanor charge of failing to report versus a charge of being an accessory to the crime?  He as good as abused that child by allowing it to occur.  He should be in jail for as long as the abuser.  They all (the aiders and abettors) should be in jail for as long as the abusers.  They should have been from the beginning.

While one can only applaud a first step in the right direction, I find it extremely regrettable that it is not for the far more serious forms of abuse that church authorities have covered up for centuries.  Compared to physical abuse that causes lifelong trauma and ruins lives forever, photos of the kind described seem tame indeed.  It is like a campaign to clean up a crime infested city that starts by first indicting someone for fraud instead of all the armed robbers and murderers than run rampant.

I was raised Catholic but left the Church when I left home and have not looked back since. The whole idea that the Church thought it could dictate what I had to believe or they would excommunicate me was more than I could accept. But, 49 years later, as a 67 year old adult who has followed news events about the Church recently, I'm more than glad I left before I married and raised children. The church is preoccupied with sex. The priest cannot marry and live normal lives. Nuns, though no longer dressed like penguins, have to remain celibate. There is nothing in the Church that is normal so how can anyone expect the leadership to act normal?

I am convinced that most priest and nuns are trying to do a good job and probably are but the environment they live in has to attract nut jobs and this keeps being proved by the diviants.

When bishops accept diviant behavor, or ignore it, they need to be locked up. But, this also goes back to my initial complaint about the Church. They were so willing to kick members out for independent thought and yet have protected priests who are quilty of breaking Church law and the criminal law of the states. So I now understand that excommunication was reserved for lay members of the Church and that the leadership could do pretty much whatever they wanted to.

The Catholic Church has to clean up its act. It lost me a long time ago and it will continue to lose members if it does not change.

That's right, Republicans.

Keep us all subsidizing corporations so that they don't have to dig into their profits for anything, including paying liveable wages, and no one will be able to afford to support market competition, leaving prices high for your favored few.

That way, the 99% is reduced to begging for help from churches, and you get your chance to exploit their desperation by proselytizing to them as they stand in line begging for food and shelter.

You should rename yourselves the Jim Jones Party.

comments.userDisplayName: Lyle Vos, Democratic Candidate for President 2012
comments.commentBody: Between ObamaCare and Dodd Frank, it should be apparent to all that the President never bothered to read the legislation he signed. I give him the credit that had he read it he would have been smart enough to veto it. He may be lazy, but I don't think he is stupid.

It's time END the for-profit insurance corporations, and replace them with universal national health insurance.

They've fought universal longterm care insurance, no matter how minimal, because their ONLY concern is their profits. How about the ill, the elderly, and people who've suffered grievous injuries? Nope, they don't count.

Repubicans side with the for-profits, because they lack the insight to recognize that they, too, might one day be old, or ill, or injured--or that this could happen to a family member of theirs. For a Republican, if something is not happening to THEM, right this minute, it's never going to happen to anyone that matters.
If the health care industry lobbied against it, then that is why Obama is removing it now. Don't fool yourself--it was probably too generous for the Capitalists to allow it.
Failure and Obama seemed to be two sides of the same coin.

Premiums through private insurance are also very high, unless you sign up at a relatively young age.  Still, Medicare does not pay for long-term care, and one has to be indigent, meaning having to spend down everything you've built up your entire life until you have nothing, for Medicaid to pay for long-term care.  And then you are a Medicaid patient with little clout.  States are enacting "look back" laws so you can't give your money/assets to your kids to avoid truly being indigent.  So unless someone comes up with a plan soon, there are going to be a lot of old people without long term care or at the mercy of nursing homes greedy for Medicaid dollars.  It's a lousy system, and it is the norm here in America.
No shame in admitting what will not work prior to implementation.
Ram-rod government legislation never works out. Private enterprise always does.
